content.raw:
# dependency issue

Possible problem building on ubuntu was that Jenkins was not installing `libqtwebkit-dev`. That has been added as a dependency and a new build [passed](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/547/).

# examples issue

Plugin examples were not building because their CMakeLists didn't have the change which was made for SearchForStuff. To avoid needing to change user code, I moved `#include <QWebView>` from `qt.hh` to `MainWindow.cc`, which is the only place it is used at so far. New homebrew [queued](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/).
content.html:
dependency issue

Possible problem building on ubuntu was that Jenkins was not installing libqtwebkit-dev. That has been added as a dependency and a new build passed.

examples issue

Plugin examples were not building because their CMakeLists didn't have the change which was made for SearchForStuff. To avoid needing to change user code, I moved #include <QWebView> from qt.hh to MainWindow.cc, which is the only place it is used at so far. New homebrew queued.

content.raw: What if people want a larger font size? Maybe if the hotkey chart is hosted online, we can provide a link to that so people can view it in their web browser and adjust the text size to their liking.
content.html: What if people want a larger font size? Maybe if the hotkey chart is hosted online, we can provide a link to that so people can view it in their web browser and adjust the text size to their liking.

content.raw:
Some programs open a browser at a specific page for their shortcut charts (Inkscape for example). Personally I find it annoying when a browser just pops up, but it could just be me.

As for hosting online, it can still be done with the embedded page as it is now - but it requires an internet connection.

So the possible combinations are:

1. Offline and embedded into Qt

1. Offline and opens the user's default browser

1. Online (hosted here?) and embedded into Qt

1. Online (hosted here?) and opens the user's default browser


I vote for 1 (maybe because that's already done :sweat_smile: )

@spaepcke
content.html:
Some programs open a browser at a specific page for their shortcut charts (Inkscape for example). Personally I find it annoying when a browser just pops up, but it could just be me.

As for hosting online, it can still be done with the embedded page as it is now - but it requires an internet connection.

So the possible combinations are:

  1. Offline and embedded into Qt

  2. Offline and opens the user's default browser

  3. Online (hosted here?) and embedded into Qt

  4. Online (hosted here?) and opens the user's default browser

I vote for 1 (maybe because that's already done )
